'Epinephrine' (also known as 'adrenaline' or 'adrenalin') is a hormone and a
neurotransmitter. Epinephrine has many functions in the body,
regulating heart rate, blood vessel and air passage diameters, and metabolic
shifts; epinephrine release is a crucial component of the fight-or-flight
response of the sympathetic nervous system. In chemical terms,
epinephrine is one of a group of monoamines called the catecholamines. It is
produced in some neurons of the central nervous system, and in the chromaffin
cells of the adrenal medulla from the amino acids phenylalanine and
tyrosine.
